qas.question: What is resistance to infection known technically as?
What is knowledge of protective antigens more complete for?
What does herd immunity offer to vulnerable people when a large enough proportion of the population has acquired immunity?
Vaccination is a way in which what may be acquired?
What is resistance to infection known informally as?
When may immunity be the best?
What is knowledge of protective antigens forbidden for?
What does herd mentality offer to invulnerable people when a tiny proportion of the population has acquired immunity?
What is the only way to lose immunity?

context: Resistance to infection (<a0_0><a4_0><b5_0><b8_0>immunity<b8_0/><b5_0/><a4_0/><a0_0/>) may be acquired <a1_0><b6_0>following a disease<b6_0/><a1_0/>, by asymptomatic carriage of the pathogen, by harboring an organism with a similar structure (crossreacting), or by <b9_0>vaccination<b9_0/>. Knowledge of the protective antigens and specific acquired host immune factors is more complete for <a2_0><b7_0>primary pathogens<b7_0/><a2_0/> than for opportunistic pathogens. There is also the phenomenon of herd immunity which offers <a3_0>a measure of protection<a3_0/> to those otherwise vulnerable people when a large enough proportion of the population has acquired immunity from certain infections.
